bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Chief of the War Department's Map Collection, June 23, 1941

div1.p: Hench requests copies of Camp Columbia maps for himself and for the Cuban Chief of Engineers of Military City. He explains his research on the yellow fever experiments and Camp Lazear.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to the Chief of the War Department's Map Collection, June 23, 1941
div1.opener:
Free
MayJune 23, 1941
Chief of the War Department's Map Collection
Army War College
Washington, D. C.
My dear Sir:
div1.p:
A couple ofAbout five weeks ago, General Ireland brought me to your War College, in
an effort to get copies of old army maps of Camp Columbia, Quemados (Havana), Cuba.
For three years I have been doing some historical researches on the work of Walter
Reed and other army surgeons in the conquest of yellow fever. I have made two trips
to Cuba and have been trying to find these old maps. I am especially anxious to
get a copy of the map of Camp Columbia for 1898 and for 1899. The sergeant in
charge of these maps showed General Ireland and me two different maps for 1899 and
suggested that I write to you formally requesting copies of these maps. In the
official reports of the Secretary of War for the corresponding years, I found mention
of these maps and also mention of a property map of Camp Columbia. You may be inter-
ested to know that this map is not in your files but is in the files of the Archives
Building, should you wish a copy of it for your own files. The Secretary of War
of Cuba very kindly put their maps at my disposal, but they only had fragments, quite
torn from long use, of two or three maps which I have not been able to locate elsewhere.
They are very anxious to exchange copies of these maps with you. They, too, would
like to have copies of the 1898 and 1899 maps.

I am enclosing photographs which I had taken of the parts of these maps and
I am so hopeful that you will have these original maps that I may have copies of them
as well as the ones I now have. Any help you can give me in this matter will be
greatly appreciated, and I am sure that General Ireland would give you further in-
formation as to the reason for my request.

To make a long story short, on my first visit to Cuba, I found that the
Cuban government had lost sight of Camp Lazear where Walter Reed did his work. They
had bought a piece of property and were about to erect a memorial on the wrong site.
Through a lucky chain of circumstances I was able to find the lost Camp Lazear, and
actually found remaining, in pretty good condition, one of the little buildings used
by Walter Reed in his experiments. I have bought this building and with friends I
am trying to raise money to restore it and properly memorialize it and also Camp
Lazear. It is in connection with these researches that I am so anxious to have
these maps of Camp Columbia.
div1.closer:
Very truly yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
Chief of the War Department's Map Collection - 2 -
May 23, 1941
P.S. The gentlemen in the map division of the Ciudad Militar
at Quemados, the headquarters of the Cuban Army, who requested that I get
him copies of the old maps of Camp Columbia from you, were Captain Garcia
Alonzo and Assistant General Velosquez, Chief of the Engineering Department.
I suggest that you either send them to me and I will forward them, or send
them directly to the Engineering Department of the Cuban Army.
P.S.H.
